conclusion: To determine how the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time changes from state C to state D, we need to analyze the properties of the gas during the transition.
The process from C to D is isothermal, meaning the temperature remains constant.
For an isothermal process, the product of pressure (P) and volume (V) is constant: \( PV = \text{constant} \).
From the diagram, as the gas moves from state C to state D, the volume decreases while the pressure increases.

premise: The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time is related to the pressure of the gas.
conclusion: Higher pressure means more frequent collisions.
Since the process is isothermal, the temperature remains constant, and so does the average speed of the gas molecules.

premise: As the volume decreases and the pressure increases during the isothermal process from C to D, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time increases.
conclusion: The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time increases from state C to state D.
